RECORD.TEXT: 882750483 PUOMC 8857096 81536/t72r 462491 8/29/1994 12:00:00 AM END STAGE RENAL DISEASE SECONDARY TO HYPERTENSIVE Unsigned DIS Report Status : Unsigned ADMISSION DATE : 8-29-94 DISCHARGE DATE : 9-21-94 PRINCIPAL DIAGNOSIS : end stage renal disease secondary to hypertensive nephrosclerosis . ASSOCIATED DIAGNOSIS : 1. diverticulitis , 2. perforated cecum , 3. acute renal insufficiency . SPECIAL PROCEDURES AND OPERATIONS : A heterotopic kidney transplant , placed in the left pelvic fossa and native left nephrectomy on 8-29-94 . OTHER PROCEDURES : 1. colonoscopy on 9-5-94 , 2. colonoscopy with rectal tube placement on 9-7-94 , 3. subtotal colectomy with Hartman pouch and ileostomy on 9-10-94 , 4. renal biopsy on 9-13-94 . HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS : The patient is a 59 year old male with end stage renal disease from hypertensive nephrosclerosis . He started on dialysis in 03/92 and has been maintained on it since . He is currently on eight times per week hemodialysis . The patient is admitted for renal transplantation . PAST SURGICAL HISTORY : The patient is status post left arteriovenous fistula creation . PAST MEDICAL HISTORY : 1. hypertension , 2. difficulty hearing , 3. gout , 4. history of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation , two prior episodes . MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION : Nephrocaps , 1 q.day , Colace 1 q.day , Allopurinol 100 q.day , Verapamil 240 mg q.day , Niferex 150 mg PO b.i.d. , Colchicine 0.6 mg PO q.day , Phoslo 667 mg q.day , Cardura 1 mg PO q.day . ALLERGIES : The patient has no known drug allergies . REVIEW OF SYSTEMS : The review of systems was negative . PHYSICAL EXAMINATION : The physical examination was unremarkable . Pulses were 2+ and symmetrical throughout bilaterally without bruits . HOSPITAL COURSE : The patient was admitted to the hospital on 9-8-94 ( please note that there is a discrepancy in dates here-transcriptionist ) and underwent his renal transplantation on the EXWAGH9T protocol . His operative course was unremarkable and postoperatively , he did well until he developed some constipation and abdominal distention several days postoperatively . He then developed massive dilatation of the cecum which was treated with multiple endoscopies and rectal tube placement . During this time , he never developed a fever , leukocytosis , or peritoneal signs . Despite these efforts and despite the lack of physical signs , on the day of the operation , he experienced a popping sensation in his abdomen while he was walking and then the onset of mild diffuse abdominal pain . An X-ray at the time revealed free air . The patient was therefore brought to the Operating Room where he was found to have a perforated sigmoid colon with gross soilage of the peritoneal cavity . He was further found to have what appeared to be an area of diverticulitis with abscess formation in his sigmoid colon . He therefore underwent a subtotal colectomy with Hartman pouch creation and ileostomy creation . The subsequent pathology report confirmed the initial impression that this was indeed diverticulitis in the setting of diverticulosis and acute and chronic inflammation with abscess formation in the sigmoid colon . The patient continued to improve postoperatively and had essentially an unremarkable course with the exception that his creatinine became elevated . A renal biopsy was then performed which failed to show signs of rejection . It was therefore felt that his elevation in creatinine was multifactorial related to the events surrounding surgery and the surgery itself . With just observation alone , his creatinine returned to a level of 2.0 by the time of discharge . At the time of this dictation , the patient is doing quite well , eating , ambulating , and taking his medications . The patient was discharged home in stable condition and will follow up with the clinic . It is anticipated that in three to four months , we will consider taking him back to the operating room to perform an ileostomy take-down . Postoperatively , the patient did develop atrial fibrillation which was felt to be related to electrolyte disturbances as well as perioperative stress . He ruled out for myocardial infarction . An echocardiogram revealed a dilated left atrium at 5 centimeters and left ventricular concentric hypertrophy without any evidence of wall motion abnormalities . A Holter monitor showed only atrial premature contractions . The patient was seen in consultation and evaluated by Cardiology and in the end , he was well controlled on digoxin , Propanolol , and verapamil . Again , he does have a history of paroxysmal atrial tachycardia for which he came in the hospital with verapamil treatment . He did have some postoperative hypertension which was controlled with Cardura and sublingual nifedipine prn . MEDICATIONS ON DISCHARGE : Prednisone 20 mg PO q.day , Imuran 25 mg PO q.day , Acyclovir 200 mg PO t.i.d. , Bactrim one single strength PO qhs , Maalox 15 cc PO b.i.d. , Zantac 150 mg PO b.i.d. , Verapamil 80 mg PO t.i.d. , Lasix 40 mg PO b.i.d. , Cardura 4 mg PO b.i.d. , Cyclosporin 300 mg PO b.i.d. , Digoxin 0.125 mg PO q.day , Clotrimazole 10 mg PO b.i.d. , Inderal 10 mg PO t.i.d.
